This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There isn't definitive evidence one or the other, and if you ask about this about here, or almost anywhere, you're just going to encounter a bunch of ideologues who don't care about the truth, never read anything that contradicts their opinion, and will just talk past each other. I'm referring both to Afro and Eurocentrists, as well as Egyptian nationalists.

The only thing that will settle the matter is DNA from a representative geographic/historical sample, but we don't have that. We have DNA from Lower and Middle Egypt from the New Kingdom to post-Roman periods. That establishes continuity with the population of Lower and Middle Egypt from this time period to the present day, but it doesn't tell us anything about Upper Egypt or any region prior to the New Kingdom.

The pic you've posted could be depicting a race similar to modern Egyptians (after all, they are on average a bit darker than Levantines and coastal North Africans) or it could be depicting an intermediate population similar to Horn of Africa population (e.g., Somalis, Ethiopians). Art tends to distinguish Egyptians from Nubians who were likely less mixed in antiquity, but it doesn't do much to distinguish them from Medjay and Punites. Both are depicted with brown skin and more gracile facial features. Could that mean that they're similar ethnically? Yes. Does it necessarily mean that? No.

Statuary is unreliable. Different statues of the same person also often appear radically different, to the point of resembling different races. Kushite pharaohs appear 100% Caucasian in some depictions, typically Sub-Saharan or mixed in others. Ptolemy, who is one person we can see with total certainty was a Greek and not a black African (we literally have ultrarealistic statues of him from Greece), appears Sub-Saharan/mixed in certain depictions. Also Egyptians and other groups can sometimes have Sub-Saharan-like features, with or without any real SSA ancestry. Many do even today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14580845
Also, Lower and Upper Egyptian statues look very different. Compare the Old Kingdom reserve heads of norther bureaucrats to those of certain Upper Egyptian pharaohs (Amenhotep III, Akhenaten, etc.). This could suggest north/south variation. Lower Egypt was also more cosmopolitan and had closer connections to the Middle East, NW African, and Southern Europe. Upper Egypt had more of a connection to East Africa, with parts of Lower Nubia, AKA, northern Sudan, being part of Egypt throughout much of its history.

It seems clear that northerners differed from southerners, but they do today as well, and modern Lower and Upper Egyptians are more closely related to one another than any other group. Upper Egyptians are more southern shifted, but their SSA is likely relatively minor (probably around 20-5% at best, though southern Upper Egypt might be a bit different). Perhaps they were always the same. Or perhaps northerners were a mostly Middle Eastern/North African population similar to today and the southerners were more Horner-like. I really don't know.

>>14580878
You're quoting a headline, not the actual study. No study ever suggested that the ancient Egyptians were more closely related to Europeans. Schuenemann, 2007 suggested that Egyptians had more SSA ancestry in post-Roman, but again, they only had samples from Lower and Middle Egypt, and they didn't go back prior to the New Kingdom. Krause, one of the other authors of the study, even suggested that if they had samples from Upper Egypt, they likely would have gotten different results. The shitty headline is due to the writer misunderstanding what he read or deliberately misrepresenting it for clickbait. The study claimed that based on these samples, ancient Egyptians were more closely related to Middle Eastern, North African, AND European populations than Sub-Saharan Africans, but this is just a function of MENA groups being relatively closely related to Europeans, and Egyptians having minor (very minor) Southern European input.

The study that demonstrated R1b in the Amarnas got the same treatment. Haplogroups only account for a small % of a person's DNA. Many black Americans (who are on average roughly 75% SSA, 25% European) have European haplogroups. Doesn't mean they're white. There are even clades of R1b originating from that peak among certain black-as-an-Ace-of-Spades Sub-Saharan groups (e.g., Chadians) that originates from Eurasian backmigration 8-5k years ago. Hitler was E1b1b, as was Napoleon. Does that mean they were black Africans? Of course not. The haplogroup originated in East Africa, the E. African pastoralists spread it to Egyptians, Egyptians spread it the Middle East, Middle East spread it to Greece/Rome (which it is still relatively common), they spread it to NW Europe. Something like that. All it likely means is that if you go far back enough, they both probably had a Roman ancestor, and if you back really, really, really far back, they had an African one. So does everyone. A point probably worth reiterating around here.

posts.com:
>If God is all good all loving all knowing and all powerful why does he allow so much pointless suffering to happen? Like rape, torture, genocide, birth defects, children with cancer, etc
The most common answer is “free will” but there are 3 huge problems with that

1. Omniscience Paradox
Strict Determinist: If God is all knowing we don’t have free will because he knows everything that we will do in the future, which means the future is predetermined. He already knows who will or will not die a sinner the moment they are born. If God is omniscient he already knows what he will do in the future too, which means he also lacks free will
Compatibilist: God can create a world where we theoretically could sin, but no one would actually want to do it so it never happens. However he hasn’t done that

2. Heaven and free will
If Heaven has free will then God is capable of creating a world of eternal bliss with no suffering, that also has free will, yet doesn’t do that

If Heaven lacks free will then free will isn’t particularly valuable. We will spend eternity with no free will anyways, our short lives with free will is working towards this as a goal. Religion portrays Heaven as a reward, something desirable, so it is admitting that an eternity of bliss with no free will is preferable over a short life filled with suffering with free will.

3. Degree of evil
God can create an exact replica of our current world, but make one heinous evil impossible to commit, like rape. We would still have free will and live in an objectively better world

If you object and say that isn’t free will, the rebuttal is God decides what is or isn’t possible. I can’t phase through walls or stop time in this world, does that mean I lack free will? Why can’t God just make rape impossible then?

>>14576388

A lot of talk about Moscow.
Operation Barbarossa was never about capturing Moscow, that was Operation Otto, the first draft of the operation, which emphasised on capturing strategic targets, Moscow included.
Operation Barbarossa was desgined to destroy the Red Army, attack on a broad front and strike at the Red Army whereever it presented itself. Moscow and Leningrad were just the direction of attack.

Hitler argued that just because you capture Moscow doesnt mean USSR is just going to surrender. They wanted to destroy the Red Army as an effective fighting force which would enable the Germans to capture the USSR without much opposition.
Hence why Operation Barbarossa failed. The germans had severely underestimated the sheer size of the Red Army, the germans had severely underestimated the Red Army production capability, the germans had severely underestimated the Red Army ability to recover and to learn from its mistakes, and the Germans had severely overestimated their own capabilities and conditions to conduct such a grand operation.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Otto

Operation Typhoon was a quickly drafted emergency operation when it became clear Barbarossa had failed and the Red Army was still fighting on, and time was running out before winter, which would mean all operations would have to be stalled, giving the USSR several months to regroup and reinforce.

But again, there was no indication that just because Moscow would be captured in Operation Typhoon. It would severely have disrupted communication and transportation in the USSR, and propaganda purpose, but the capture of the city wouldnt have changed anything for the Germans in the strategic matter, they would still face the same problems.
Given the USSR knew what the Germans intentions were, and the Germans themselves were not interested in any terms of negotiation except total destruction of the USSR, its unlikely the USSR would just have decided to surrender

This image is part of a transcription of a recording of Hitler talking to Mannerheim in the summer of 1942.

There was no reasonable possibility of Germany winning against the Soviets, though of course there's some tiny fraction of a chance that the perfect storm could have carried them there. Such a thing wasn't going to happen so it's hardly worth considering.

The first World War had the crippling of Russia as a major goal of the Germans before going in. They saw the threat Russia posed as it slowly industrialized and as French investments helped them develop their railways, meaning that as time dragged on Russia would become more and more able to draw upon its massive resources to rapidly bring soldiers to the front and adequately equip them for battle.

The Empire won in the east, lost in the west, and the Russians retook most of the land and under the communists began industrializing harder and faster than any state had in history. It wasn't just that, though - the Germans had double, then triple the latent industrial power of the Soviets as they marched on, but at every year from 1940 the Soviets produced more tanks, guns, and planes than the Germans.

The Nazis faced the nightmare the Empire tried to stop, and never were going to win. 1914-1918 was the only chance the Germans ever had.

A good one would be when Diocletian basically invented European feudalism to save the Empire. Diocletian's one of my least favorite people ever and I wish the Empire had collapsed in the Crisis of the Third Century rather than becoming what it became and setting the stage for the feudal Europe that followed, but it certainly worked and bandaided the Empire together for another couple hundred years.

Diocletian required that sons follow in the trade of their fathers. He also made the office of Emperor more aloof and autocratic than it had been before. He increased the bureaucracy of the state and raised taxes. He cracked down on personal liberty and religious freedom, and tried to implement price controls on goods. All but the most bootlicking statists would consider most of those reforms evil, but it did prolong the empire for a minute.

>>14569521
Easy. They don't really do it anymore, but societies all over the world until modern times used horrible torture as a punishment for crimes. You can argue that what we do today--incarceration or extremely humane execution--isn't a "horrific crime" (that is kind of a vague term but I'm trying not to get into philosophy here), but I'm sure most people participating in public judicial torture in the Middle Ages would agree that it was horrific, and probably, other than a few sadists, didn't relish doing it. But they would have believed that it prevented crime in the society via deterrence, so they would consider it a necessary evil and do it anyway. Hell, if you were very religious, you might believe that burning a witch was a necessary evil to protect the society from the witch's curses and the wrath of God, even though you didn't enjoy setting a pretty young woman on fire.

Shit like breaking at the wheel, burning at the stake, drawing and quartering in Europe, or death by a thousand cuts or some of the other nasty shit they did to people in China, were all done with a good rationale of deterring crime and protecting the royalty of the state to prevent anarchy and chaos. I don't believe they were all sadistic bastards, most of them were probably holding their nose and doing it reluctantly because the really believed it was the right way to maintain a stable society.

>>14575822
Depends on what is important to you. It wasn't constant misery for everyone involved the way Hollywood sometimes portrays it--but very few systems are. Most types of society that made it into the history books were at least stable and not too uncomfortable (except for mass slavery which is its own issue), if they weren't the people would revolt and something else would emerge.

But relative to most other modes of organizing society throughout history, feudalism was very low on the social mobility scale, which is an important attribute to me. I don't like the idea of being legally bound to a certain trade or a certain piece of land. It usually coincided with censorship of speech and an enforced state religion. And even though in theory the lords were the stewards and protectors of the peasants in their domain, more often than not the lords abused their power and mistreated their serfs. Also, the feudal system existed to free up the nobility to fight constant, small-scale wars with each other. It has the benefit of protecting most peasants from mass conscription into armies as is the norm in most centralized societies, but you lose the benefits of centralization too. In a massive empire like the Ottomans, or the Romans or Chinese, during the height of their power, everyone pretty much lived in peace, unless you were near an active frontier. In feudal Europe, all the states were smaller, so everyone was in closer proximity to the constant small-scale wars and the abuses that always come along with that. Especially major cities were under siege ALL THE FUCKING TIME which is miserable for their inhabitants, and is not the case in a centralized empire.

Plus, the patchwork of tiny states make it really difficult to raise a massive organized army to contend with attacks from large empires. Doesn't matter how badass your knights are if you only have a handful of them. Like how the Mongols always kicked the Europeans' teeth in

Now, that's not an inherent characteristic of feudalism I guess, but the combination of the patchwork of feudal states plus the level of military technology at the time definitely encouraged it.

>Historically, was goldsmithing easier or harder than iron or bronze?

Goldsmithing was way, way, way, easier.
Gold is a really soft metal (you can literally bite it and dent it) that you could, in the past, find in sizable native surface deposits and in alluvial gold rivers. It was easy to collect, had a lower melting point, and was easier to work with.
Which means you could make some pretty elaborate pieces of artwork out of gold.

>any response to my so-called refutation of free will is "cope" and "pilpul" because... it JUST IS, okay?!

Let's get this out of the way. "Free will" in the sense that man possesses causal agency over his own actions is, of course, immediately evident to any sane, rational person. The very existence of alternative choices when determining our course of action is proof enough.

If however, you mean "free will" to mean that man's volitional faculty is unbounded by any constraints and influences, then that is patently false. Man is not autonomous in the way that God is; what He wills always comes to pass, whereas what we will may change or be obstructed by some obstacle (physical handicap, mental unpreparedness, lack of financial resources, etc.)

The point in Exodus is that Pharaoh's hardness of heart is a direct outworking of God's decree. As He said in Exodus 9:16 "For this very purpose I have raised you up, so that I might show My power in you, and that My name might be declared in all the earth." Does that absolve Pharaoh of guilt? Not at all, for He knew the will of God (to let the Hebrews go) as spoken by Moses, but suppressed the reality of YHWH's sovereignty as a result of his unbelief. God gave Pharaoh over to his stubbornness so as to multiply the wonderful works of His mighty deliverance for Israel's sake, that they might believe in Him.

The long and short of it is that simply because God is the ultimate cause of all things in the final sense does not make void the reality of secondary or efficient causes that He has established per His providential decree.

Do you have any other questions, anon?

>>14579413
In 700 AD, French ("Frenċisċ") referred to the Franks. By 1000 AD, it referred to the inhabitants of France, who were French-speakers, with French manners, chivalrous tastes, castles, convents and schools; French blood and a common heritage. The Latin word Romanus, too, didn't have the same meaning in 1 AD and in 300 AD.
Translating Franci as "Franks" seems pointless insofar as "Frank" is a loan from Old French while "French" is a native English word. It creates unnecessary confusion, because the early medieval Germanic confederation was already confined to legends and the popular imaginary by 1066, while the French-speaking inhabitants of France were the only ones who still called themselves Franks, in Old French texts such as the Song of Roland or the later Conquest of Constantinople by Villehardouin. Or you arguing that Clovis' jolly band of warriors are the ones who landed on England's shores that fateful day?

>>14579561
Tribal Frankish identity was replaced by a political Frankish identity as the Frankish kingdom cemented its position in Europe. Following the Treaty of Verdun, the political communities in France and Germany remained the same, and there was still a desire to reunify the Frankish kingdom. All the way until Charles the Fat's deposition, it was still no different from the sub-kingdoms that had existed under Charlemagne and even before him.
Only after the deposition of Charles the Fat did the collapse of central power into feudalism accelerate uncontrollably and what we could today see as permanent divisions between the kingdoms, but that can only be said with foresight. The political community in Germany and in France on Charles' deposition was more or less one in the same, taking over a century and successive wars to break it apart. But after Otto the Great unified the various tribes of Germany, Franks, Saxons, Alemannians, and Bavarians, Frankish political identity was replaced by an imperial or German political identity.
Meanwhile, on the French side, the accession of the Capetians over the Carolingian dynasty completed the schism between the two political communities. There was no Francia to reunite, no Frankish political will, hence no Franks to speak of. You can of course argue that the "Franci" in the Bayeux Tapestry and the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle were Franconians, but that's a statement dreamed up by the mentally deranged. Just open a Latin dictionary and you'll see that I'm right.

>>14580189
No, and by the 12th century it was also allegedly impossible to tell them apart.
The Danes had this law called murdrum whereby an unknown man who was killed was assumed to be a Dane, with the implication that the tithing was higher than if the man was English. The Normans reinstated this law but called it presentment of Englishry—an unknown man who was killed was assumed to be Norman, but if he was proven to be English then the hundred would be excused from any fine. Attempts to prove that the victim was English were common yet unsuccessful, which shows that Normans and Anglo-Saxons were hardly distinguishable by that point.
Keep in mind that this occurred within the span of 100 years while the Normans were England's ruling class. Arguing that the opposite was true for France in 1000 AD after over 500 years of intermingling, knowing that Frankish migrations to Gaul predate even Clovis, is just incredibly stupid.

>recent academic studies in Latin America have widely challenged this notion, considering it a flawed and ideologically-based reinterpretation of the colonial period.
>Pilar Gonzalbo, in her study La trampa de las castas (2013) discards the idea of the existence of a "caste system" or a "caste society" in New Spain, understood as a "social organization based on the race and supported by coercive power".[14] Joanne Rappaport, in her book on colonial New Granada, rejects the caste system as an interpretative framework for that time, discussing both the legitimacy of a model valid for the entire colonial world and the usual association between "caste" and "race".
>Similarly, Berta Ares' 2015 study on the Viceroyalty of Peru, notes that the term "casta" was barely used by colonial authorities which, according to her, casts doubt on the existence of a "caste system". Even by the 18th century, its use was rare and appeared in its plural form, "castas", characterized by its ambiguous meaning. The word did not specifically refer to sectors of the population who were of mixed race, but also included both Spaniards and Indians of lower socio-economic extraction, often used together with other terms such as plebe, vulgo, naciones, clases, calidades, otras gentes, etc.[16]
>In a detailed analysis of Mexican archival records published in 2018, Ben Vinson came to a similar conclusion.
>Often called the sistema de castas or the sociedad de castas, there was, in fact, no fixed system of classification for individuals, as careful archival research has shown. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The 1828 presidential election, which saw the revival of the two party system, was the most hotly contested and nasty one since 1800. Andrew Jackson ran for president a second time on charges that he'd been robbed of a legitimate victory four years earlier and denouncing the "Tariff of Abominations" against unpopular incumbent John Quincy Adams. Although Adams himself was too highbrow to engage in personal attacks, his supporters had no qualms about charging Jackson with being a blood-stained barbarian who hanged prisoners-of-war without trial during campaigns in the War of 1812 and in Florida. Jackson supporters accused Adams of being an aristocratic elitist--("a man who fights versus a man who writes") and of several corrupt activities including charges that he had acted as a pimp while serving as US ambassador to Russia and had procured prostitutes for the tsar. Adams had also purchased a billiard table and a chess set for the White House, paid for out of his own pocket, which Jackson supporters magnified into an entire gambling parlor.

Worse than that were charges that Jackson had engaged in a bigamous marriage to his wife Rachel, as she had left her first husband and married him before the divorce was finalized. Rachel had not wanted to go to Washington DC or serve as First Lady, but she was spared from this when she passed away at the end of the year from a stroke. Jackson was heartbroken at her death and blamed his political enemies for it.

When the electoral votes were counted in December, Jackson had buried Adams in a huge landslide with 178 electoral votes to 83 and 55% of the popular vote to 44%. Adams only carried the traditional Federalist strongholds in the Northeast.

>Chief Justice Marshall, no fan of Jackson, administered the oath of office to him on the steps of the Capitol Building on March 4, 1829. The inaugural ball was a chaotic mess with hundreds of spectators rushing in to greet the new president, tracking mud and dirt all over the White House. Some newspaper editors decried the rule of "King Mob." Given Jackson's known reputation, Britain dreaded his election as president, but he proved surprisingly more conciliatory than hoped. While John Quincy Adams had been rebuffed in a rude attempt to obtain US access to the Caribbean ports, Jackson came hand-in-hat to London and politely asked if American merchant ships might be allowed to come there. The Foreign Office, impressed with this gentlemanly display, agreed.

>Andrew Jackson was 63 when he entered office, the oldest president yet, and in poor health from numerous wounds sustained in duels and on the battlefield. A musket ball was lodged in his abdomen; as it was extremely close to his spine, doctors judged it too risky to try and remove it. Jackson suffered a persistent hacking cough that sometimes brought up blood. It was doubtful if he would even live to finish one term as president, let alone two.

>Perhaps a less edifying legacy of Jackson's presidency was the spoils system which would result in large portions of the Federal bureaucracy being fired each time the White House changed parties, to be filled with the supporters and hangers-on of the party now in power, many of whom were less than fit to hold office. The most notorious patronage appointment Jackson made was one Samuel Swartwout, the port collector of NYC, who absconded with $1.2 million in customs tolls (over $33 million in 2020 dollars) and fled to England with the loot. He became known as the first man to steal a million dollars from the US government.

>In retrospect, the spoils system was inevitable. There had not been a party changeover since the "revolution of 1800" three decades earlier, and many Federal posts were occupied by doddering old men, some with their commissions signed by George Washington, hanging on into their 80s and doing little more than drawing breath and a salary. There is a story of an elderly postmaster pleading with Jackson to let him keep his job as it was all he had. He had fought in the Revolutionary War, he explained, and to prove it opened his shirt to reveal a scar on his chest. Jackson remarked to an aide "Do you see that? That fellow has a pound of British lead in his chest. By the Eternal, I will not fire the old man."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Jackson's first term was dominated by the Nullification Crisis when South Carolina nearly erupted in war over the 1828 "Tariff of Abominations." The Southern states were taken by surprise that the president, a native son, slammed his fist down and threatened to lead an army against any state that would secede or defy Federal authority (a revised tariff schedule was later made that defused the crisis).

>Taken from a modern POV, South Carolina's temper tantrum over a tax seems faintly ridiculous but in the 1830s, the Revolutionary War, fought over taxes, was still in living memory. Another thing that may not be understood to the modern day person is that in Jackson's time the Constitution itself had not yet acquired the semi-sacred status it has today. Many men, including Jackson, had known its authors in person and were aware that it was a compromise document no one had been entirely satisfied with. The idea that a state could back out of the "pact" of the union and the Constitution was still a widespread idea, and one that would eventually boil over.

posts.com:
>In 1831, the Nat Turner Rebellion erupted in Virginia like a hurricane when a slave preacher named Nat Turner claimed God had commanded him to lead his followers in an uprising. The revolt was quickly put down and Turner himself burned at the stake. But the incident, which coincided with the arrival on the scene of the infamous William Lloyd Garrison and his newspaper The Liberator, marked a new and ever-increasing series of quarrels over the South's "peculiar institution." Once upon a time, slavery was perceived as a dying institution--the Constitution was written at a time when most were sure it had only a few more decades left. Until the 1820s, abolitionist support had been stronger in the South than the North.

>The event of the cotton gin changed all that and the rise of Garrison and other radical abolitionists made the South steadily more paranoid. Abolitionists however were not a lot more welcome in the North; Garrison once made a miraculous escape from a lynch mob in Boston, and the abolitionist preacher Elijah Lovejoy of Springfield, Illinois had his printing press destroyed by mobs several times before he was finally lynched in 1837. Abolitionist groups attempted to flood the South with propaganda literature often aimed directly at slaves; since most of them couldn't read, the pamphlets tended to feature graphic cartoons of slaves being whipped or otherwise abused. Many postmasters, fearing for their safety, refused to deliver these inflammatory items to Southern post offices.

In the book by Josephus, Against Apion, he references a no longer extant book by the historian Clearchus of Soli, a student of Aristotle, that recounts a meeting between Aristotle and a Jew who could speak Greek and knew Greek ideas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: National Socialism functionally and legally abolished the bourgeois materialistic fetish that is the sanctity of private property rights.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>“In the capitalist system of the past, money became the goal of work for the employee as well as for the employer. It was the individual’s wages that appeared to give work a sense of purpose. The employee saw the employer simply as someone who 'earns more.' And the employer regarded the staff of workers in his firm only as a means to an end, an instrument for him to earn more. The consequences of this thinking were ominous. Should the working man have any ambition to work anymore when he says to himself, 'I'm only working so that the man over in the office can earn more?' Can a business deliver quality work if everyone thinks only of himself? . . . Labor—its purpose, its honor, the creative value, the German worker as a master of his trade and a proud, capable working man, all this became secondary. Reorganizing labor does not just mean removing the crass material deficiencies of life. It must penetrate the relationship of person to person."
Leistritz, Hans, Der Schulungsbrief 5/1937, p. 163

>“The goal of the German Labor Front is the creation of genuine cooperative fellowship and efficiency among all Germans. It must see to it that every single person can find a place in the economic life of the nation according to his mental and physical capabilities that will insure his highest level of achievement. In this way, the greatest benefit to the overall community will be realized."
Klüver, Max, Vom Klassenkampf zur Volksgemeinschaft, p. 287

>“No one has the right to elevate himself socially above another because some outward circumstance makes him appear better...The loftiest individual is not the one who has the most, but the one who does the most for everyone else.... The honest man, even if he is poor, is worth more than a wealthy one possessing fewer virtues."
Zitelmann, Rainer, Hitler Selbstverständnis eines Revolutionär, p. 211

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Hitler himself wrote that bringing a particular class of people into the community “does not succeed by dragging down the upper classes, but by elevating the lower. This process can never be carried out by the higher class, but by the lower one fighting for its equal rights."
Zitelmann, Rainer, Hitler Selbstverständnis eines Revolutionär, p. 206

>He passed laws making exploitation of labor a punishable offense: “This must be considered necessary as long as there are employers who not only have no sense of social responsibility, but possess not even the most primitive feeling for human rights."
Zitelmann, Rainer, Hitler Selbstverständnis eines Revolutionär, p. 206

>In January 1934, the government enacted the Law for Regulation of National Labor, containing 73 paragraphs. At a press conference, Reich’s Labor Minister Franz Seldte defined the foundation of the law as removal of “unsavory” class distinctions which had previously contributed to the collapse of the German economy, in favor now of “emphasizing the concept of social esteem,” and the leadership idea in business life.
Klüver, Max, Vom Klassenkampf zur Volksgemeinschaft, p. 108

>"The Law for Regulation of Wages introduced guidelines for calculating salaries. Based on the principle of comparable pay for equal demands on an individual’s time and energy, its goal was to guarantee a decent standard of living for everyone who worked hard. The law stated, “Grading of salaries must correspond to the actual demands of the work involved. It therefore doesn't matter what job the individual has. Personal engagement is the decisive factor." The regulation further called for an adjustment in salary for employees with unavoidable financial hardships, in order to guarantee their standard of living. Even time lost from work due to weather conditions became a factor. It also required that every citizen receive pay for overtime."
Klüver, Max, Vom Klassenkampf zur Volksgemeinschaft, p. 250

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>The law’s [the "Law for Regulation of National Labor" of January 1934] vocabulary replaced the terms “employer and employee” with “leader and follower.” It designated respective roles in this way: “The leader of the facility makes decisions for the followers in all matters of production in so far as they fall under the law’s regulation. He is responsible for the welfare of the followers. They are to be dutiful to him, in accordance with the mutual trust expected in a cooperative working environment." The law imposed moral obligations on both. The German economist Dr. Hans Leistritz described them in these words: “Both the facility leader and the followers are under the commission of the people. Each always faces the same choice, of whether he should fulfill his duty or become caught up in self-serving goals. Both the facility leader and the followers can face disciplinary action that punishes transgressions against this social code of honor.” The law cited examples, such as “if a contractor, leader of the facility or other supervisory personnel misuse their authority in the workplace to unethically exploit the labors of members of the following or insult their esteem.” The law likewise held workers accountable for “jeopardizing the harmony of the workplace by intentionally stirring up their co-workers."
Leistritz, Hans, Der bolschewistische Weltbetrug, p. 35

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>One of the most proactive advocates for the working class was the leader of the DAF, Dr. Robert Ley. A combat airman during World War I and former chemist, Ley had joined the NSDAP in 1925. His words lent emphasis to the regulations governing treatment of labor: “Today the owner can no longer tell us, 'my f𝗮ctory is my priv𝗮te 𝗮ff𝗮ir.' That was before, that’s over now. The people inside of it depend on his factory for their contentment, and these people belong to us.... This is no longer 𝗮 priv𝗮te 𝗮ff𝗮ir, this is 𝗮 public m𝗮tter. And he must think and act accordingly and answer for it.
Klüver, Max, Vom Klassenkampf zur Volksgemeinschaft, p. 104 (emphasis mine)

>In October 1934, Hitler published a decree defining the nature and the tasks of the DAF. He wrote, “The German Labor Front is to insure harmony in the work place by creating an understanding among facility leaders for the justifiable requirements of their followers, and balancing this with an appreciation among the followers for the circumstances of and for what is feasible for their factory.” In this sense, Hitler assigned the DAF an educational mission as well. It was but a single element of an extensive, lengthy process of “total inward re-education of people as a prerequisite” to achieve “genuine socialism."
Zitelmann, Rainer, Hitler Selbstverständnis eines Revolutionär, p. 220

It’s a radical and total adjustment that the grown-up is no longer capable of making. Only the young people can be changed."

Reinhardt, Fritz, Die Beseitigung der Arbeitslosigkeit im Dritten Reich, p. 61

>The state appointed the Price Oversight Commission to stop businesses from decreasing production or delivery of certain commodities, especially foodstuffs, for the purpose of creating artificial shortages to inflate prices and overcharge consumers. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Business owners and directors were responsible not only for sound fiscal management of the company, but for the protection of employees from abuse. This was not presented as benign advice from the government. It was a law word for word. Income and profit were no longer the primary objectives of an enterprise. The wellbeing of its associates became a concurrent purpose. The Reich’s Ministry of Labor published a table of offenses under the category of unjust exploitation of employees. These included paying salaries below fixed wage scales or failure to compensate workers for overtime, refusing to grant employees vacations, cutting back hours, providing insufficient meals, inadequate heating of work stations, and maintaining an unhygienic or hazardous work environment. Supervisors were even disciplined for browbeating their staff to work harder.
Klüver, Max, Vom Klassenkampf zur Volksgemeinschaft, p. 117

>In 1938, the periodical Soziale Praxis (Social Custom) reported on “serious punishments” meted out to landowners who quartered their hands in inadequate accommodations. Klüver, Max, Vom Klassenkampf zur Volksgemeinschaft, p. 117

posts.com:
>Labour organization has also been reformed through the Organization of Labour Act (January 20, 1934). Connected with that measure is a revised Labour Courts Act, as well as an Act concerning the Introduction of the Work Book (February 26, 1936) which provides the authorities with the data necessary for a planned distribution of labour. Rules governing labour contracts have also been laid down. The Act for the Protection of Wages in Homework (June 8, 1933), and the Homework Law (March 23, 1934) the essential part of which protects the worker from a lowering of wages, but which also makes it possible to prohibit homework tending to endanger life, health, and morality, further, the Hours of Work Act (July 26, 1934), the Act concerning Hours of Work in Bakeries and Confectioner's Shops (June 29, 1936). The eight-hour day is prescribed as a general rule. In concerns dangerous to health the time of work must be reduced. In the sphere of labour protection we have regulations concerning work with compressed air (May 29, 1935), an Act regarding the Accomodation for Workers in the Building Trade (December 13, 1934), which provides for a healthy and adequate accomodation for workers (male and female) in coal mines, in roller and hammer works and in the glass industry (March 12, 1933). In addition to the reorganization of sickness, invalidity and accident insurance, social insurance as a whole has been reformed so as to ensure its efficient and economical working.

>The National Socialist State has not sought to make a compromise between the National Socialist and the capitalist organization of industry and labour. In place of the opposition of Labour and Capital, of employer and employed, the Labour Organization Act has set up the Works Community, which exists to serve the whole people. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>The work in each individual factory or business is therefore carried out for the common benefit of people and state, and its success or failure affects the fate of the whole nation. The position of the employer as leader of his business is subordinate to this task. His work in cooperation with the workers he employs is based not on mutual services rendered, but on the common work done for the nation. The employer's position as leader does not therefore mean that he is master in his own house and can do what he likes. It means rather that he is responsible for what his firm does for the community. The employer is bound to his workers by the fact that they are all participating in the labour of the nation. The essence of this cooperation lies in social honour, which means performances of duty, and respect for every kind of work. To offend against this principle of honour is to infringe the order of things embodied in the Labour Organization Act. The form given to the Works Community necessitates that it should be self-governing. The organ of this self-government is the Mutual Trust Council, which consists of the leader of the firm and members elected by the workers. Its task is above all to assist in the drawing up of the works regulations, to see that suitable measures for protection against accidents are taken, and to strengthen mutual confidence.

German Law and Legislation by Dr. Erich Schinnerer, University of Berlin, Published by Terramare Office, Berlin, 1938 pages 20-21

>The Courts of Honour have passed sentences on account of malicious exploitation of labour for the following actions: the inadequate payment of work in violation of wage agreements, retention of wages, nonpayment for overtime, excessive work, bad conditions of board and lodging, refusal of holidays, and breaches of important regulations for the avoidance of accidents. It is unbelief, plain and simple. Those who have witnessed or known someone transformed by the power of the risen Christ, yet deny the Spirit's work in producing fruit in their life through the ministry of grace are essentially 'blaspheming' in that they are attributing the action of God to something else, while knowing full well that it is.

Consider the context in which the phrase originally occurs in Matthew 12:31-32 and Mark 3:28-30. The Pharisees had just seen Jesus drive out demons by "the finger of God", something that most Jews took as a sign of Jesus being the very same prophet spoken of by Moses in Deuteronomy 18:15-19 and the "anointed one" (i.e. Christ) promised by Isaiah. But rather than acknowledge the origin of these supernatural deliverances as being from God, the religious leaders sought to slander the Lord by saying that "he cast out demons by the prince of demons".

Though they were without excuse for their unbelief, they sought all the more to confute and gainsay Him for the sake of envy, as Pilate quickly discerned.

Hence, the unpardonable sin is that of suppressing the truth in unrighteousness, and spitting in the face of the bountiful evidences that God has afforded men so that they might believe. As it is written: "The one believing in the Son has eternal life, but the one not obeying the Son will not see life, but the wrath of God abides on him." John 3:36.

Hope this helps some.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14579313
Some people classify it (aka Advaita Vedanta) as being a type of idealism while others disagree with this classification. It identifies reality as being the pure, infinite, immutable consciousness of Brahman; however Advaita understands this consciousness to be different from all mental activity including thoughts and in fact they say that this consciousness lacks all mental activity including thoughts, which differs quite considerably from types of idealism which say that the universe is comprised of thoughts and other mental-phenomena instead of the standard materialists view of it being comprised of physical objects that gives rise to mental activity. Despite this difference though Advaita is still saying that reality is inherently conscious or sentient.

posts.com: Would the world be a better place if the British Empire was still around?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14575032
That's a question that really depends on the circumstances. Did it continue more or less as it did in the early 20th century, with the cooperation of local peoples, or did the decolonization movement still happen and Britain only kept the empire through brutal repression?

Assuming the British Empire continued without descending into a permanent state of civil war, I would say it would definitely have benefitted the colonies themselves and the world in general. Corruption is the number one problem for most developing countries; Britain provided an administrative class that were both competent and honest. They were also fairly effective in dealing with security problems; unlike France or Portugal they were never forced out of any of their colonies by military action, suppressing revolts in Malaysia and Kenya fairly easily. Many of their former colonies had their development stymied after the British left by internal political struggles and civil wars.

There's also the point that India wouldn't have been partitioned, which would have been immensely beneficial for the subcontinent.

It still begs the question: in what form could the British Empire have survived? As I said above, continuing down the road it was on would have torn it apart eventually. However, I think that if London had ever seriously pursued the Imperial Federation idea, allowing the white colonies equal say in the government of the empire while granting local autonomy to the rest, they could have found a compromise that would produce a workable system.

The problem with the British Empire was not that the colonies were tired of it but that London was - and I say specifically London and the ruling class rather than Britain as a whole. Even in the 1930s the British elite seemed to think that empire had run its course and was coming to an end, while the empire itself still assumed it would go on forever. If the British leadership had shown any initiative or backbone, it might well have.
